metadata.title: 5.6 Ambiguous Triangle and the Sine Law
metadata.creator: Thiago
metadata.abstract: This document is for testing purposes only. The material that is presented here should be treated as an example only.

section.p: Ambiguous Triangle and the Sine Law

column.p: Can a triangle be formed given AB = 4 cm, BC = 10 cm, and ABC = 30° ?

section.p: justify0.90center80 As you can see, it is sometimes impossible to form a triangle with the given information. A "triangle" with two adjacent sides and an opposite angle given are known as a SSA triangle. When solving triangles using sine law, this configuration may result in 0, 1 or 2 triangles. This is known as the ambiguous case.
